name: citrus-x-aurantiifolia
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: Heat, sun, humidity and drought tolerant once established.
edibility: Fruit juice is edible and used in drinks, syrups, jams and jellies, and baking.  It is used as a sauce over meat and fish, and also in marinades.  Also used in sherbets, sorbets, ice creams, and the famous key lime pie.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
fruit-description: Spherical, green when unripe, yellow when ripe.  Seedy, and has a thinner rind than persian lime.
flower-description: Showy 5 petaled white flowers, purple-tinged when new and pale pink or white when mature, appear in springtime and late summer in racemes composed of 1-7 flowers per raceme. They may be fragrant or unscented. The flowers have both male and female parts.
leaf-description: Has glossy elliptical to oblong evergreen leaves, similar to the leaves of the orange tree.  The leaves have crenulated margins and are leathery in texture measuring between 1½ - 4 inches in length by ¾-2¾ inches wide. When young, its leaves are light purplish in color, maturing to dark green above and paler green beneath. The leaves are distinctively aromatic when crushed.
stem-description: New year's growth is green in color.
poison-symptoms: Vomiting, diarrhea, depression; potential dermatitis. The fruit is edible, skins and plant material can cause problems.
uses: In Persian culture it is dried and used in cooking.  Leaves are used for headaches and colds.  Oil from lime is used in soaps, gum, and sweets.  Lime juice can be employed as an antioxidant when squeezed over fresh-cut fruit to prevent it from browning.
